PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  Conceptual Wastewater Masterplan (2010-2025) was approved by the Government of 
Nepal (the government) in 2010 and investment under Kathmandu Valley Urban Environment 
Improvement Project is envisaged in 2013. In order to carry out due diligence on technical, 
economic, financial, social, governance, poverty and social, and safeguards for subprojects 
under the ensuing loan, a project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is necessary. The 
proposed  PPTA  will  also  suggest  the  ways  to  suitably  coordinate  with  ongoing  and  other 
proposed projects in water and wastewater sectors in Kathmandu Valley.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, administered by the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
remuneration and per diem for counterpart staff, office accommodation and transport, and 
contingencies and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The PPTA will require about 50 person-months of consulting services (15 international 
and 35 national). A team of consultants, who will work under the overall guidance of the ADB 
project officer and the team leader, will be recruited under one package using the quality- and 
cost-based  (QCBS)  method  of  selection  with  a  standard  quality-cost  ratio  of  80:20  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). A simplified technical proposal will be used for the selection of a firm. The summary of 
consulting services requirement is presented in Table A4.3.

5.  The tasks assigned to the PPTA team will be to (i) review the conceptual wastewater 
masterplan  for  Kathmandu  Valley  and  recommend  packages  for  sewerage  network  and 
wastewater treatment plants including recommendations for the energy efficient technologies for 
wastewater treatment (target: zero energy balance); (ii) analyze the problem of intermixing of 
storm water with wastewater and recommend most appropriate solutions;  (iii) assess technical, 
procurement, and management capacity of the key agencies involved in the project; (iv) carry 
out financial management assessment of KUKL, and such other agencies that would utilize 
imprest advance or statement of expenditure (SOE) procedures; and based on the financial 
management  assessment,  recommend  appropriate  funds  flow  mechanism,  disbursement 
arrangement, and other financial and institutional arrangements; (v) carry out feasibility study of 
selected  subprojects,  including  engineering  designs  and  financial  and  economic  analyses, 
incorporating  considerations  on  climate  change  mitigation  and  adaptation  including  O&M 
embedded civil contracts for sustainability; (vi) carry out social and poverty analysis including 
surveys and collection of dis-aggregated data; (vii) prepare required safeguard documents; (viii) 
assess the potential for private sector participation in investment as well as operation and 
maintenance (O&M), reflected in the proposed project design; (ix) assess the governance risks 
in the areas of financial management, procurement, and corruption, and develop risk mitigation 
measures based on the assessment; (x)conduct due diligence for monitoring and evaluation, 
and institutional capacity; (xi) develop a framework for cost recovery considering affordability, 
viability and willingness to pay  (xii) prepare the draft project administration document describing 
how the executing agency and the implementing agency will implement the project and deliver 
the outputs on time; and (xiii) propose implementation schedule, procurement plan, detailed 
cost estimates and financing plan, as well as required consultants’ inputs (including terms of 
reference) under the project. 
 
6.  The  PPTA  consultants  will  also  provide  support  to  enhance  project  readiness  and 
expedite project start-up activities. They will undertake training of relevant officials involved in 
the  project,  and  assist  the  executing  agency  and  implementation  agency  in  undertaking 
advance contracting, such as recruitment of consultants for the project. The consultants will also 
prepare necessary documents required for project processing and implementation. 
 
7.  Team  Leader  and  Wastewater  Management  Expert  (international)  will  have  an 
engineering  background  with  experience  and  knowledge  of  project  processing  and 
management, especially ADB projects. He/she will manage the overall implementation of the 
PPTA and will be responsible for achievement of all the outputs. In addition, he/she will make 
technical inputs in developing components of sewerage network and treatment plants. Deputy 
Team  Leader  and  Wastewater  Management  Expert  (national)  will  have  an  engineering 
background with experience and knowledge of project processing and management, especially 
ADB projects at national level in Nepal. He/She will support the team leader in all aspects of 
project preparation, including coordination with the various stakeholders. He/she will also make 
technical  inputs  in  designing  sewerage  subprojects.  The  Wastewater  engineers  (one 
international and one national) will support the team leader in developing sewerage subprojects. 
Wastewater  Treatment  Experts  (one  international  and  one  national)  will  analyze  various 
alternatives  and  recommend  appropriate  technological  solutions  for  Kathmandu  Valley

wastewater  treatment  plants.  Financial  management  expert/economist  (national),  will  have 
experience of working on financial assessment and economic and financial analyses of projects, 
and will undertake the required financial management assessment and economic and financial

help propose an effective institutional arrangement for the project. Social and Environmental 
safeguards  experts  (national)  will  undertake  due  diligence  of  social  and  environmental

PPTA and the project implementation. Procurement Expert (national) will support the executing 
agency and implanting agency to undertake advance actions for enhancing the procurement 
readiness  of  the  project.  Sewerage  Geographical  Information  System  (GIS)  Experts 
(international) will support the executing agency and implementing agency to update the GIS 
already being developed under ongoing projects and develop methods to institutionalize the use 
of GIS in wastewater operations. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
8.  The Ministry of Physical Planning and Works (MPPW) will be the executing agency 
responsible for overall strategic planning, guidance and management of the PPTA and for 
ensuring achievement of the outcomes.  KUKL will be the implementing agency and the existing 
Project  Implementation  Directorate  (PID)  in  KUKL  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  planning, 
implementation, monitoring and supervision of all PPTA activities, (ii) reporting to KUKL Board 
of Directors, MPPW and ADB, and (iii) coordination of all PPTA activities. A PPTA Steering 
Committee, to be chaired by Secretary, MPPW, will be established to provide policy guidance, 
oversee PPTA implementation and ensure cooperation of other agencies. The PSC will include 
representatives as decided by the MPPW and ADB. Disbursements under the TA will be made 
in accordance with the TA Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).    
 
9.  The government will provide (i) all relevant documents, data, statistics, information, and 
maps  that  are  available  at  the  disposal  of  the  government;  (ii)  appropriate  and  qualified 
counterpart staff, including their field per diem and field transportation; (iii) Project Director, PID, 
KUKL as the Project Director for the PPTA; (iv) office accommodation and office equipment, 
including desks and chairs, and local communication; (v) logistical assistance for the workshops 
and seminars, including the venue, and identifying and inviting the invitees; and (vi) utility costs, 
covering electricity and water, etc. The equipment procured under the TA will be turned over to 
the government at the end of the TA. 
 
10.  The TA will be implemented from December 2011 to July 2013. The proposed PPTA 
processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
